Much love, Caryn
Posts.Title: The prognosis in not good RobinWendy BrokenHeart

Posts.Content: Mar 29, 2009 11:01AM CarynRose wrote: There are many many mutations that raise the risk of getting breast or ovarian cancer.  They have only discovered a small number of them and declared them to be deleterious. So, when you come up 'negative', it could be an uninformed negative result.  As Dr. Narod recently published, family history can trump a negative BRCA test.  Two suggestions:  1) Find a certified genetic counselor 2) go to the FORCE website where you can learn anything you need to know about hereditary cancer.  www.facingourrisk.org  Best of luck, Caryn

Posts.Content: Aug 21, 2009 09:03AM CarynRose wrote: I avoided anyone with STage IV before I progressed there.  I couldn't even be in the same room.  It was too confronting to me.  Maybe it was superstition, but I would NEVER lurk on the mets site or thread.  Now that I am Stage IV, I hear non-metsers offering me platitudes.  I try not to get mad and try to take well meaning comments as good, healing energy and I never refuse that.   I do agree that too many forget the lives of us metsters.  They figure you are either a 'survivor' or dead.  Not a thought to the extending the lives of those of us with mets.  I don't donate to Komen because of that.   Best wishes, Caryn

Posts.Content: Sep 15, 2009 01:56PM CarynRose wrote: Marsha, I had WBR for leptomeningeal mets earlier this year (in addition to full spinal radiation).  I was told that I would lose my hair and it might not grow back.  I was also told that I'd probably lose 10 years from my brain and that I'd be very fatigued.  I wouldn't say that I lost 10 years of memories, but rather the quickness of the workings of my brain was affected.  I used to have a great sense of direction; now, not so much.  I used to be very good with words and vocabulary; now, I lose words or have to find others to describe what I'm trying to say.  My short term memory is less accurate -- I can be introduced to someone and 5 minutes later, not recall their names.  The issues are bothersome, but I haven't forgotten my lifetime of memories. Best wishes, Caryn

I just have to prove to them that I'm worth more than $4000. Isn't this crazy?! Caryn Dx 6/28/2007, IDC, 2cm, Stage IV, Grade 3, 0/3 nodes, mets, ER-/PR-, HER2- Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: I NEED YOUR PRAYERS!! CarynRose pitanga

Posts.Content: Jun 29, 2010 10:15AM CarynRose wrote: I went through what you are going through plus spinal radiation too.  The steroids will make you weak and the radiation will fatigue you, but slowly, your strength will return.  The strange side effect I discovered (and recently found out that others have had) was that I lost about 50% of my appetite and lost 60 pounds (I needed it).  If you don't want to lose any weight,  supplement your diet with Ensure or Glycerna.   Cheers, Caryn
Posts.Title: Please tell me this will get easier (wbr) dorfar pee

Posts.Content: Feb 23, 2009 04:02PM CarynRose wrote: I don't want to scare you, but more and more leptomeningeal mets are being found lately in those of us with mets.  You can't find it with MRI's, PET/CT's, etc.  The only way they found mine was with a couple lumber punctures.  I had headaches and back pain.  You might want to insist your doctor do the test just to rule that out.  Best wishes, Caryn
Posts.Title: Tired of having to ask this. magsandmattsmom SpunkyGirl

Posts.Content: Aug 19, 2009 12:23PM CarynRose wrote: Hi Heidi's Brother!  Thank you for taking such good care of your sister.  My name is Caryn and Heidi and I have been corresponding since I've been through WBR and spinal radiation.   Here are some answers to your questions: 1) The major side effects that I experienced were fatigue, hair loss (after 10th treatment), and with the spinal rads, internal burns in my esophagus - very painful to swallow. 2) The effects were gradual.  It took several days before I was affected by the fatigue. 3) The effects last months....in certain issues, they are still affecting me. 4)  Oh yes, I was so weak that I needed a walker.  And I still do, but that is because of the decadron.  The quality of the weakness was different than any chemo weakness I had experienced.  5) I didn't have hallucinations per se, but I detected a unique odor whenever I got zapped.  I was told that other had heard things or seen things.   Hope that helps, Hang in there!! Caryn
Posts.Title: Whole Brain Radiation - Side effects Heidi_Ho-s_Little_Bro hezzy

Posts.Content: Aug 12, 2009 03:09AM - edited Aug 12, 2009 03:11AM by CarynRose Heidi honey, I had leptomenigeal mets 10 months ago, October 23 to be exact.  I woke up one morning and the left side of my face was paralyzed.  Two LPs later, they found cancer in my CSF.  Here's what we did: They immediately put in an Ommaya Reservoir in the top of my head.  They infused the chemo directly into that reservoir.  We used Methotrexate.  It was very harsh on my and within 15 minutes of treatment I was weak as a kitten.  We did this for about 2 months and it was effective, but I also got menegitis.  Now they use a drug called Depocyt that is much milder and you receive it only once ever two weeks instead of weekly. After chemo was finished , they gave me 14 whole brain radiation treatments and full spinal radiation treatment.  It was torture and made me more fatigued than any other treatment I've had.  I lost my hair on treatment day 10.  But the end result is that 10 months later, my CSF tests completely clear. I reached out to find ladies who also had this and my inspiration came from a lady named Deb who is now 27 months out and busy planning her daughter's wedding.  When she responded to me, she couldn't spend a long time with me because she was leaving on a cruise.  BTW, I'll be on a cruise in September.  Bottom line -- it's not a death sentence.  It's hard, but you can be fine.  I go to the Cancer Treatment Centers of America and my doctor is Dr. Rudolph Willis. Please feel free to contact me via email at carynrose at aol dot com. Caryn

Posts.Content: Feb 20, 2009 09:18PM CarynRose wrote: BRCA 1 and 2 are only two of the possible millions of mutations that can cause hereditary cancer.  They are the first two that they found and for which a test was 'patented'.  So, if you come up negative, but dont' have a verifiable relative who has had cancer  who comes up positive, you can be what they call 'uninformed negative'.  In other words, you could have another unknown mutation -- or the mutation may or may not be one that will cause a higher risk for cancer.  My family had very little history of breast cancer... .must my maternal grandmother and it turns out I inherited the mutation from my FATHER!.   A visit with a certified genetic counselor will help you get the info. you need for yourself and for your kids.  Keep in mind that it's always better to be proactive on these things because surgery, chemo and rads do take their toll on the body and there is not guarantee that the cancer won't come back. Cheers, CarynRose

Posts.Content: Jun 11, 2010 08:26PM CarynRose wrote: It may also be your age.  You probably look relatively healthy and most people's perception is that BC hits women at least in their mid-forties.  She probably doesn't understand what you are going through.  Maybe your cancer team can write down a 'schedule' that explains surgery, chemo, radiation, etc.  Then you can meet with your boss and adjust her expectations.  Perhaps how you can make up the time?  How long have you worked there?  If her non-compassion starts getting in the way of your health, you might be eligible for FMLA time off. All the best, Caryn

Posts.Content: Apr 2, 2009 08:13PM - edited Apr 2, 2009 08:15PM by CarynRose Well, with my COBRA extension, I have a total of 29 months which started 10/01/07.  I actually got sick with the recurrence in June of 2007, so if you count from there, then I should be eligible for Medicare this June.  I'll be 49, one year short of eligibility for AARP.  My DH turns 50 in December and then, he can join and we can get their supplemental insurance. So, if I have reached my limit on my current insurance and can't go on Medicare til June/July, what do I do with monthly bills that are $80,000.  Should I get on to DH's plan as a supplemental? (I have not had a lapse in coverage in 20 years)  Would they pay what my BC/BS won't? And then going forward, when I qualify for Medicare and I've passed the age of 50, I can have AARP Supplemental and Medicare.  Then I would just have to find a prescription plan.  None will match what I have now --$3 for generic; $10 for namebrands.  Do you have any recommendations for prescription plans?  Love, Caryn

Posts.Content: Sep 15, 2009 06:52PM CarynRose wrote: My brain mets were not actual lesions, but rather, a gloppy coating of cancer cells along my entire central nervous system, from brain to spinal cord.  I could not drive during treatment, and frankly, still can't, or rather shouldn't.  Very frustrating to lose that independence.  I did lose my hair, especially from the top of my head.  I was told that it may or may not come back, so for now, I look somewhat like someone with male pattern baldness.  The hair on the sides of my head is growing in (after 7 months), but I am still sparce on top.  Cheers, Caryn

Posts.Title: BRCA1 & 2 testing shelloz1 gfigman

Posts.Content: Dec 12, 2009 09:06AM CarynRose wrote: Mossy, At U of PA, I think I know the oncologist you are referring to.  I saw her for a second opinion for my metastatic recurrence and she told me "if there is anything you ever wanted to do in your life (ye old bucket list), I would do it now.   Well, after they got me off the floor and I sat with the social worker for 2 hours, I was able to head to NE Philly to Cancer Treatment Centers of America.  The oncologist there asked to look at the bottom of my foot and commented that he saw no expiration date there, so he didn't think a prediction of my demise would be prudent.   Two and a half years and two recurrences later, I'm still here and NED. I have a real partner, not only in my doctor and his staff, but also with every member of the staff there.  We are all committed to have me live a long life with a "chronic" disease and an excellent quality of life. I wish the same for you. Love, Caryn
Posts.Title: The "get your affairs in order" talk mossybaby RobinWendy

Posts.Content: Sep 1, 2009 05:40PM CarynRose wrote: Kirby,  Finding out you are Stage IV sucks.  I was shocked because the idea never occured to me.  I had heard I had an axillary tumor, but when the oncologist called me the told me the CT showed nodules in the lungs, I realized that I had mets and that I was Stage IV. You asked how you get past the anger, betrayal and defeat.  All I can tell you is that you can take it one day at a time, one step at a time.  And when you feel angry, don't try to stuff it or worry that you are killing yourself because you are having a negative thought.  Just let it flow and before you know it, the next emotion will come, and then the next, and the next.  It's been two years of mets for me, with triple negative BC and four years before that of remission from the original early stage cancer after that treatment.  It's been a roller coaster ride.  Just when you think you are at the top, you can plunge down.  I just took it as it came, did what the doctors, the naturopaths, the reiki masters, acupuncturists said to do.  I prayed and meditated and opened myself up to the love, support, and powerful healing energy sent to me by my support system (lots of them online).  Just this last month, after spending most of the summer in and out of the hospital, I found out that I am in remission and that my floating cancer cell blood test shows no detectible cancer cells.  That means that there is a 90% that I have two years before a serious cancer flare up comes up.  An who knows what they will come up with by then? You will get over the shock, but probably will wistfully long for the 'old norma'.  Just know that we all do.  You are not alone.  G-d doesn't make mistakes, so there must be a purpose in all this.  I hope this helps. All the best, Caryn
